awd_titl_txt: INCLUDES Initiative (Conference): Reimagining STEM Innovation and Entrepreneurship by Centering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion
awd_abstract_narration:
This conference award, funded by NSF’s Eddie Bernice Johnson INCLUDES Initiative, is creating an actionable vision for broadening participation in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) innovation & entrepreneurship (I&E). Using iterative design and ideation during a conference workshop, followed by working groups that center the perspectives and experiences of individuals historically excluded from STEM, participants from different backgrounds and identities will create a core vision and roadmap for a reimagined, inclusive I&E ecosystem. This project is expected to meaningfully advance the field by redefining approaches to STEM I&E, opening multiple new pathways to advance inclusive innovation, and generating new definitions of entrepreneurship, disruption, and success. The conference is also expected to create economic opportunities and benefits to those across the I&E ecosystem who have been denied these opportunities. The conference will bring together a diverse core network of participating STEM I&E experts and expanded partnerships that will help to carry the re-envisioning and systemic change work forward. 

There is an urgent and critical need for STEM I&E to engage diverse populations and create opportunity for the energy, creativity, and contributions of all Americans. This conference award centers the lived experiences of marginalized populations, helps the field learn where gaps and barriers are most persistent and how they are experienced by people from underrepresented populations, and creates opportunities to think differently about systemic constraints through research. Questions that will be explored include: What values need to be enacted within/outside of the ecosystem? What structural changes are needed? What resources are needed to enact the vision? Small working groups will convene in the months following the conference workshop to identify and further develop five actionable recommendations for moving the vision forward. Anticipated outcomes are an initial framework that identifies attributes of an inclusive STEM I&E sector, development of a series of co-created strategic recommendations, published action agendas describing a rationale and implementation steps for each recommendation, and a workplan for further exploration and implementation of additional strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF INCLUDES Conference Award: Reimagining STEM Innovation and Entrepreneurship 

by Centering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion

Outcomes Report 

Submitted 12/04/2024

Award Title: Reimagining STEM Innovation and Entrepreneurship by Centering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion

Federal Award ID: 2317317

Report Submission Period:  09/15/2023 - 08/31/2024

 

Summary/Description: (800 Words or less)

 

The "Reimagining STEM Innovation and Entrepreneurship by Centering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion" project was designed to address systemic barriers that have long impeded the participation of underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) innovation and entrepreneurship (I&E). This project centered the voices and lived experiences of over 35 experts from underrepresented groups—including Black, Latinx, Indigenous, women, disabled, and low-income individuals—to develop a comprehensive framework and actionable recommendations. These recommendations aim to guide future initiatives in building inclusive and welcoming STEM I&E ecosystems across higher education institutions, government bodies, and other key STEM I&E stakeholders.

The project unfolded in three main phases, with Phases 2 and 3 funded by this award. Phase 1, which was not funded by this award and occurred prior to the funding period, laid the groundwork for this project, and consisted of a half-day workshop where participants identified five key subject areas that provide critical levers and opportunities for meaningful change. These areas included: 1) K-12 STEM pathways, 2) establishing diverse modes of communication and storytelling, 3) building community and belonging, 4) leveraging policies and research to amplify and sustain the participation of diverse groups in STEM I&E ecosystems, and 5) addressing access to intellectual property and capital for entrepreneurs from underrepresented groups. Phase 2 involved virtually convening one working group per subject area, with each working group composed of experts from academia, industry, and policy. Each group developed strategic recommendations related to their specific key subject area. Phase 3 featured a one-day in-person workshop, where participants refined their recommendations. Following the workshop, the VentureWell INCLUDES project team worked on drafting a public-facing report that detailed the framework and recommendations developed throughout the project. 

Key outcomes and insights for the project include 20 actionable recommendations, such as promoting asset-based communication that reflects diverse experiences, expanding accelerators for entrepreneurs from underrepresented groups, advocating for inclusive policy support, and building connections among startup networks, investors, and entrepreneurial communities to improve access to financial capital. Additionally, four main themes emerged across all working groups: 1) the key subject areas explored by each working group were interconnected, 2) inclusive collaboration involving underrepresented groups is crucial for developing equitable STEM I&E ecosystems, 3) psychological safety fosters belongingness, lessening isolation for diverse individuals in STEM fields, and 4) addressing systemic barriers requires long-term commitment and resources to bridge participation gaps. 

This project adopted a groundbreaking approach by directly involving individuals from underrepresented groups in STEM I&E, placing those most impacted at the forefront of designing and proposing solutions. By centering their voices, the project contributed to a large body of work focused on diversity, equity, and inclusion. The insights and strategic recommendations that emerged from this collaborative effort not only address historical barriers but also present innovative methods for fostering long-term change. 

The project broadened participation by engaging individuals from diverse backgrounds and incorporating their unique perspectives into actionable strategies. These efforts can enhance education by informing curriculum development and classroom practices that prioritize inclusion and support of underrepresented students in STEM fields. Furthermore, this work has the potential to contribute to creating a more inclusive workforce by applying the developed framework across various sectors. The strategies outlined can help educational institutions, government agencies, industry, and other organizations build environments that foster equitable environments in STEM and beyond.
